subject: Re: Re: [junit] How do you test your Java EE 5 applications?
msgSnippet: Hi Ajay, I actually have looked at Ejb3unit, which you can see last in my initial post. To me it s a bit of a hassle to get started as I didn t quite get it
messageBody:
Hi Ajay,

I actually have looked at Ejb3unit, which you can see last in my
initial post. To me it's a bit of a hassle to get started as I didn't
quite get it simply by reading the mini-tutorial on their web page. In
that tutorial I would have liked some motivation to why you have to
inherit from a certain class in a given situation. But there are lots of
other things I also would have liked an explaination to. Add to this
that it doesn't seem to have (if you know of one, please tell me) an
active community where you can get help, like a forum or mailing list.
That leaves each user pretty much alone with a small tutorial and the
Javadoc, of course it might be enough for some people with a lot of
time.

Could you tell us a bit more about what you have used Ejb3unit for? And
how you got comfortable with using it? What's your motivation for using
it, instead changing your design and separating business logic into
POJO's which are called by the beans so that you're able to unit test
them in the normal way?

Best regards,
Kent

>>> jadhavajay@... 2008-01-24 07:41 >>>
Pls. checkout http://ejb3unit.sourceforge.net

This tool allows you to unit test EJB 3.0 Entity & Session beans out
of
container.

Regards,
Ajay Jadhav
http://www.divinet.co.in


On Jan 23, 2008 5:53 PM, Kent Larsson <kent.larsson@...> wrote:

> = How do you test Java EE 5 applications =
>
> I've researched several JUnit extensions without finding any I like.
> How do you test your EJB components?
>
> = One possible approach without any JUnit extension =
>
> One approach I've heard is to have the session beans as dumb
forwarders
> of requests to normal objects. And implement the actual business
logic
> in normal Java classes. That way you're able to unit test your
business
> logic using a normal JUnit approach. What do you think of this
approach?
> And do you have any sources with more information about it? What if
> there are instances of EJB stuff created inside the class? (Do we
need
> JMock?
>
> One example of this approach:
>
> // I guess a common interface is something you would want
> ProcessShoppingInterface {
> int methodA(int inputOne, int inputTwo);
> }
>
> // The normal class, doing some (imaginary) business logic in the
> methoA method
> // we can easily test this class using a normal JUnit test
> ProcessShoppingCartClass extends ProcessShoppingInterface {
> int methodA(int inputOne, int inputTwo) {
> int tmp = inputOne;
> for (int i=0 ; i < 99 ; i++) {
> tmp += inputTwo/i;
> if (tmp > 1000)
> return tmp;
> }
> return tmp * 2;
> }
> }
>
> // This is the session bean which simply forward calls to an
instance
> of the
> // class where the actual logic resides
> ProcessShoppingCartStatelessSessionBean extends
> ProcessShoppingInterface {'
> ProcessShoppingCart normal = new ProcessShoppingCart();
> int methodA(int inputOne, int inputTwo) {
> return normal.methodA(inputOne, inputTwo);
> }
> }
>
> = Ejb3Unit =
> I have tried this a bit. But it's pretty hard to get started as the
> introductory material are sparse and doesn't give explanations about
why
> certain things are used, and which alternatives we had. It might be
a
> great framework for testing, however I am having a hard time with it
as
> I would have needed more documentation and tutorials.
>
> Have you tried it? What do you think, is it worth the hassle? Have
you
> got any tips on how to get started with it?
>
>



--
Regards,
Ajay Jadhav
